<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_sync_:
```c
static int lfs_file_sync_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    if (file->flags & LFS_F_ERRED) {
        // it's not safe to do anything if our file errored
        return 0;
    }

    int err = lfs_file_flush(lfs, file);
    if (err) {
        file->flags |= LFS_F_ERRED;
        return err;
    }


    if ((file->flags & LFS_F_DIRTY) &&
            !lfs_pair_isnull(file->m.pair)) {
        // before we commit metadata, we need sync the disk to make sure
        // data writes don't complete after metadata writes
        if (!(file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE)) {
            err = lfs_bd_sync(lfs, &lfs->pcache, &lfs->rcache, false);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }
        }

        // update dir entry
        uint16_t type;
        const void *buffer;
        lfs_size_t size;
        struct lfs_ctz ctz;
        if (file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE) {
            // inline the whole file
            type = LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT;
            buffer = file->cache.buffer;
            size = file->ctz.size;
        } else {
            // update the ctz reference
            type = LFS_TYPE_CTZSTRUCT;
            // copy ctz so alloc will work during a relocate
            ctz = file->ctz;
            lfs_ctz_tole32(&ctz);
            buffer = &ctz;
            size = sizeof(ctz);
        }

        // commit file data and attributes
        err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &file->m, LFS_MKATTRS(
                {LFS_MKTAG(type, file->id, size), buffer},
                {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_FROM_USERATTRS, file->id,
                    file->cfg->attr_count), file->cfg->attrs}));
        if (err) {
            file->flags |= LFS_F_ERRED;
            return err;
        }

        file->flags &= ~LFS_F_DIRTY;
    }

    return 0;
}
```

I selected pointer-typed usages and pointer arguments in this function that should be reviewed to determine whether the pointee types can/should be const-qualified. Other fragments in the function do not need investigation under Rule 8.13 because:
- Local non-pointer objects (e.g., the local struct variable ctz and scalar variables like type, size) are not subject to pointer const-qualification.
- The local pointer variable buffer is already declared as const void * (so it satisfies the rule).
- Members declared const in the provided type definitions (for example, the cfg pointers inside lfs_t and lfs_file_t) are already const-qualified and need no further inspection for this rule.
- Operations that write through the file pointer (for example, file->flags |= LFS_F_ERRED and file->flags &= ~LFS_F_DIRTY) clearly require a non-const lfs_file_t * and therefore are not candidates for adding const.
- Calls or macros that likely modify the referenced state (e.g., functions that commit or sync caches) may legitimately require non-const pointers; those specific call sites are included above for investigation, while other non-pointer code paths do not need review for this rule.
